Description: Egyptian terracotta figure plaque of Harpocrates with side knot. Head only. Crudely made. Mould-made and solid with crude back. Covered in red slip or paint. Red-brown Nile silt fabric. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
A number (143?) is written on the back in pencil, more likely a catalogue number than a findspot reference.

Similar examples of these simple Egyptian ithyphallic Harpocrates figure plaques are commonly dated to the 5th and 4th centuries BC (Fischer 1994, Pl.1, nos.1-3; Török 1995, Pl.34, nos. 48-49 in a similar fabric; Bayer-Niemeier 1988, Pl.83.6, no. 456). Very similar, but not same mould series as examples found at Naukratis, now in Cambridge MCA (NA614, NA588) and Bristol Museum (H841). Possibly a fragment of a phallophorous figure, a procession that usually involves a pair of Bes’ and a pair of priests holding Harpocrates’ phallus, who has a naked female tambourine player (wearing a diadem) on his shoulder or head. See Herodotus’ discussion of 5th century processions (History II:48). 5th and 4th century BC parallels of such groups (or fragments of a phallophorous group) have been found at Saqqâra (Martin 1981, Pl.23, 306 probably early 4th century BC), Memphis (Anthes & Bakry 1959, pl.30, no.206; Anthes et. al. 1965, 129 nos 255 and 256; Petrie Museum UC48384-5, UC48391, UC33595-602, UC33605 see also UC47868 and UC48382) and Naukratis (Gutch in Hogarth 1899, pl.12.143; Cambridge, Museum of Classical Archaeology NA581, NA601; Bristol, City Art Gallery & Museum H2805; Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.389; Bolton Museum 1886.31.17, 1886.31.16 and 1886.31.15; Brussels, Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire A.1837; Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-E.4694, E.4654 and see E.4720 and possibly the British Museum GR 1973,0501.1, GR 1973,0501.22, GR 1973,0501.32) and unprovenanced (Török 1995, pl.34, no.50; Bayer-Niemeier 1988, pl.83.4, no.455; see also Besques 1992, pl.71 E381; Fischer 1988, nos 1-3). Anthes, R. & Bakry, H. S. K. 1959. Mit Rahineh 1955, Philadelphia. Anthes, R., Habachi, L., Yoyotte, J. and Jacquet, J. 1965. Mit Rahineh 1956, Philadelphia. Bayer Niemeier, E. 1988. Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik. Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann, 1. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten. Melsungen. Besques, S. 1992. Catalogue raisonné des figurines et reliefs en terre- cuite grecs, étrusques et romains, 4, 2. Epoques hellénistique et romaine. Cyrénaïque, Egypte ptolémaïque et romaine, Afrique du Nord et Proche- Orient. Paris. Fischer, J. 1994. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber, Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen, Tübinger Studien zur Archäologie und Kunstgeschichte 14, Tübingen. Martin, G. T. 1981. The sacred animal necropolis at North Saqqâra: the southern dependencies of the main temple complex. Egypt Exploration Society, Excavation Memoirs 50. Török, L. 1995. Hellenistic and Roman terracottas from Egypt. Roma.
